title: Can someone else sue for a debt that was already won in a judgment, but then the defendant filed for bankruptcy and included it?
question: Me and my wife, along with my sister-in-law and her husband rented a house. All 4 adults were on the contract. The landlord and his wife were both on the contract. They illegally kept our security deposit. I personally sued him and won a judgment. He and his wife just filed for bankruptcy. Since my sister-in-law and the landlord's wife were not included in the judgment, can my sister-in-law legally sue her after the bankruptcy to try and get our money back? Not trying to be petty, but this guy was HORRIBLE to us, stole our money, and is doing everything he can to not pay us back. This person is trying to claim both his residence and the rental home as personal residences so he doesn't lose them, is a VP of his company, and is most likely hiding other big assets. Is this a lost cause??
answers:
You should contact a bankruptcy attorney in your area to determine creditor rights. You may be entitled to some funds if the trustee to the landlord's bankruptcy case is able to acquire assets. Alternatively, you may want to file an adversarial proceeding claiming possible fraud. Talking to a creditors rights attorney in person will help you to better understand possible options. The attorney will also be able to look up the case and analyze the situation better.

If the bankruptcy did not have any assets, your sister-in-law will not be able to collect any money. Although they didn't receive notice of the bankruptcy, if the case is "no asset", then they would not have received anything anyways and they still will not receive anything.

I'm sorry for your loss and having to deal with the guy. Good luck.

It is unlikely that other parties to the contract can pursue him for a debt that the court has already rendered judgment. Unless the 3 other adults have separate cause of actions against them, they could not sue again. The issue was already adjudicated. But if your judgment was only for 1/4 of the damages, then they may have a claim. It matters a lot to find out if they filed Chapter 7 or 13. As a general rule, any debt incurred prior to filing the BK is dischargeable debt. If this guy's BK is a Chapter 7 "no asset" case, no one will have claim to collect for past debt (some exceptions for fraud and other criminal acts). In fact, all unsecured creditors will get zero from his estate. But as you mentioned, if he has lot of assets and his hiding assets, his case may be an asset case and you may be notified by the court to file a proof of claim to be paid. If he has filed a Chapter 13, you will be required to file a proof of claim to be paid. If you have information regarding his assets and his business ventures, I would suggest informing the trustee of his case and/or make sure he properly disclosed them in the BK Petition. Talk to an local BK attorney who can help you navigate these options.

If landlord has reason to believe he owes money to your sister and her husband, they should have been included as creditors in landlord's bankruptcy even if they never sued landlord.

None of the creditors (you, your wife, your sister-in-law, or her husband) will be able to sue or otherwise try to collect if the debt is discharged in landlord's bankruptcy.

One possible exception would be if you successfully contest the discharge of the debt in bankruptcy. You might want to consult a creditors' rights attorney to see if you have possible grounds to contest discharge of the debt.

When a BK is filed there is an automatic stay of all proceedings against the parties who actually declared BK.

You could hire a BK lawyer and pursue the claim aggressively, but practically speaking, you may be better off just filing a claim in the BK.

In California the LL holds the security deposit but the money is the tenant's and not the LL's money. Take a look at the law around civil code 1950.5. In essence, if the LL did not provide a proper accounting, they took your money. I am not sure how the BK judge will view that argument but legally, that is what occurred.

Make sure that EVERYONE files a claim in the BK using the proper local form (its on the court's web site) and do NOT miss the claims bar date ! Be early !

You may want to go to the initial meeting of creditors and see if they let you very politely ask non accusatory questions of the debtor.

Good luck

Greg G

I agree with Ms. Ware's answer above generally. If the landlord listed both you and the other parties to the contract as a potential creditor in the case, then unless you objected to the discharge of this debt in particular within the times allowed, then you will be discharged notwithstanding your judgment.

I agree with the other poster that you could obtain a copy of the bankruptcy petition to see if you were "treated" in the case. Typically, in a "no-asset" chapter 7 case, all debts are discharged whether listed or not. But, in a chapter 13, if the debt is not "provided for" in the plan, then it may not be discharged.

I can appreciate the frustration, though.
